repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Adds a lua module which can evaluate elisp code.

Currently designed to be compatible with emacs 29.4.

**TODO:**
- [ ] **Test**
- [ ] **Documentation**
- [ ] **Simplify the init process**
- [ ] **Licensing**: Emacs lisp (and thus this module) is licensed under GPLv3, which is not compatible with the license of Neovim (MIT).
- [ ] **Speed**: Lua is much slower than C (around 10x slower), which is a problem when for example loading `loadup.el`.
- [ ] **More functions**: Only 304 out of 1775 (17.1%) functions are currently implemented.
- [ ] **Remove non lua5.1 features**: `goto` and `\x` are only supported in luajit.
- [ ] **Luacheck and types**

**Init:**
(Presumes that you have emacs 29.4 installed on linux.)
```lua
local elisp_path = '/usr/share/emacs/29.4/'
local elisp = require('elisp')
_G.vim_elisp_data_path = vim.fs.joinpath(elisp_path, 'etc')
_G.vim_elisp_load_path = {vim.fs.joinpath(elisp_path, 'lisp')}
_G.vim_elisp_optimize_jit = true
_G.vim_elisp_compile_lisp_to_lua_path = vim.fs.joinpath(vim.fn.stdpath('cache'), 'elisp')

elisp.init()

-- -- Load the standard init library. (Takes a long time. (15s-2min))
-- elisp.load('loadup.el')

-- -- (or) Load the most important standard libraries.
-- elisp.load('emacs-lisp/byte-run')
-- elisp.load('emacs-lisp/backquote')
-- elisp.load('subr')
```

comment_regular_data.body: can you make it so that it crashes neovim when it sees `;;; -*- lexical-binding: nil -*-`

> can you make it so that it crashes neovim when it sees `;;; -*- lexical-binding: nil -*-`

No (unless you have a compelling argument for it to do that)
by forcing lexical binding we can finally get rid of legacy code which uses dynamic binding

> by forcing lexical binding we can finally get rid of legacy code which uses dynamic binding

Yeah, but I would rather wait until upstream(GNU-emacs) decides to default to lexical binding.
Yeah, neovim is a great OS that lacks a decent text editor. Wait, what?

> Emacs lisp (and thus this module) is licensed under GPLv3

This is going to cause headache for company lawyers (although that might be considered a feature).
Does this pr mean we can use emacs plugins in neovim?

> Does this pr mean we can use emacs plugins in neovim?

When it's complete, yes.
In case this is not an elaborate April Fools joke (in which case, well played!), it doesn't look like any of this needs to be in core and can just as well (and hence should) be a separate plugin.

> More functions: Only 304 out of 1775 (17.1%) functions are currently implemented.

So when this is done, Neovim codebase will double?

> So when this is done, Neovim codebase will double?

If we presume that the lines per function-implementation stay the same, it will result in a total of 119071 lines, which is only 9.2% of the total neovim-codebase's lines.
Also, for anyone curious, here is the repo where the work of this is happening: https://github.com/altermo/nelisp/ (Note that I'm in the process of rewriting it in C)

title: feat: emacs-lisp
